46:59 Caption: The game can't be described as attractive. We are hoping against hope that the second half will bring more exciting moments and goal opportunities. It's difficult to say if one side enjoyed any superiority over the other in the first half. The home team's main weapon is fast counter-attacks, while the away side attempts to hold onto the ball for as long as possible.

48:59 Caption: The performance from both sides could be described as average. There were only a few stirring moments and the fans probably expected more from this game. The game was quite balanced and neither team had any obvious advantage. The home side relied on counter-attacks for most of their chances, while the away side's tactic was kick and rush football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a tightly contested Serie A match, Udinese emerged victorious against AC Milan with a 2-1 triumph at the Stadio Friuli. The game was characterized by a series of fouls, offsides, and set-pieces, with both teams struggling to find fluidity in their play. Nevertheless, the fans witnessed moments of brilliance, particularly from the experienced Antonio Di Natale, whose leadership and attacking prowess were pivotal for Udinese.

The match commenced with AC Milan kicking off proceedings. Within the opening minute, Udinese showed their intent when their forward line forced a shot on target, which marked the beginning of a busy day for Milan's defense. Despite the early pressure, the ball was cleared and went out of play, setting a precedent for numerous throw-ins and corners throughout the game.

Early in the first half, both teams were aggressive in their approach, leading to frequent fouls. By the second minute, Udinese committed their first foul, only for another one to follow soon after, giving AC Milan a couple of indirect free-kicks, although they couldn't capitalize on these opportunities. The match saw a series of back-and-forth exchanges, with throw-ins and clearances punctuating the gameplay. Udinese's corner in the sixth minute was another missed chance as the ball once again went out of play.

The game had its share of offsides and missed chances. Jeremy Menez of AC Milan, in the 11th minute, found himself beyond the last defender, but his run was halted by the linesman's whistle for offside. Moments later, Ignazio Abate's attempt to create danger in front of the Udinese goal was thwarted by the vigilant defense.

Despite frequent interruptions, both teams attempted to build up play through set-pieces and indirect free-kicks. Notably, Luca Antonelli's cross into Udinese's penalty area in the 15th minute posed no threat as the defense easily dealt with it. Udinese's defensive unit remained intact under pressure, consistently clearing the ball from their half.

Around the 18th minute, Udinese's captain Antonio Di Natale frequently found himself caught offside, reflecting the home side's eagerness to push forward. The midfield battle was intense, with both sides exchanging periods of possession but without creating clear goal-scoring opportunities. Guilherme's attempt to feed the ball into the penalty area for Udinese was blocked, leading to another throw-in.

As the game approached the half-hour mark, Udinese's Maurizio Domizzi earned a yellow card for a challenge, signaling the physical nature of the match. AC Milan's Gabriel Paletta went down injured but soon rejoined the fray, signifying the resilience of players on both sides.

Despite an array of set-pieces and half-chances, neither team found the breakthrough in the first half. The ball frequently went out of play, resulting in multiple throw-ins and corners, which both defenses managed to clear effectively. Di Natale's shots for Udinese either went off target or were blocked by the diligent Milan defense.

The first half ended similarly to how it started – scrappy and physical. An attempt by Luca Antonelli to score for Milan was disallowed by the referee for a foul, adding to the frustrations of Filippo Inzaghi's side. The first 45 minutes concluded leaving both teams with much to ponder, and the fans hoping for a shift in momentum in the second half.

As the second half began, AC Milan made an early substitution, bringing on Adil Rami for the injured Gabriel Paletta. Udinese kicked off the half with renewed vigor and mounted pressure on Milan's defense. Silvan Widmer of Udinese was quick to make his mark, delivering a cross that the Milan defense managed to clear away. Consistent fouling disrupted the flow, but the home side continued to push forward.

Things took a turn in favor of Udinese shortly after. In the 13th minute, taking a corner kick, Antonio Di Natale delivered a well-placed ball deep into Milan's penalty area. Giampiero Pinzi met it with precision, striking the ball into the bottom left corner beyond the reach of Diego Lopez. The home supporters erupted in joy as Udinese took a 1-0 lead.

AC Milan responded by trying to claw back into the game. However, their efforts were met with stiff resistance from the Udinese defense, particularly from goalkeeper Orestis Karnezis, who showcased excellent reflexes. AC Milan seemed to improve, enjoying more possession and trying to find an equalizer through well-coordinated play. Suso of AC Milan managed to get a shot away from the edge of the box, but it was quickly blocked by the defense.

The game saw tactical substitutions with Udinese replacing Alexandre Geijo with Cyril Thereau to add fresh legs and maintain their lead. Milan's intense efforts were eventually rewarded when Ignazio Abate sent another cross into the box, only for it to be intercepted by Karnezis.

The home side doubled their lead in the 29th minute. Guilherme initiated a quick and incisive move, laying the ball off to Badu, who made no mistake in slotting it into the back of the net, leaving Diego Lopez helpless. This 2-0 lead for Udinese put significant pressure on the visitors to recover from.

Milan didn't give up, continuously pressing forward. Their persistence paid off in the 42nd minute when Jeremy Menez took a corner and delivered it into the box. Alessio Cerci, who had been brought on as a substitute, sent a beautiful cross to Giampaolo Pazzini. Rising high, Pazzini headed the ball into the left side of the goal to make it 2-1. This goal infused a glimmer of hope for the away side.

Despite the late goal, Udinese managed to hold onto their lead by maintaining possession and thwarting AC Milan's attempts to pump the ball into the box. Substitution strategies by both teams influenced the closing moments of the game but didn't result in further goals. The game saw some more minor fouls and stoppages, with Udinese showing impressive resilience against Milan's late pressure.

The final whistle blew, signaling Udinese's hard-earned victory. The game, although marked with numerous stoppages and fouls, saw moments of class and decisive finishes from Udinese that ultimately secured their win. Pinzi and Badu's goals made the difference, while Di Natale's experience continually put pressure on Milan's defense. AC Milan's lack of fluid play and inability to capitalize on set-pieces haunted them throughout.

The post-match analysis would focus on Udinese's disciplined defensive effort and Milan's struggle to find a rhythm and capitalize on their possessions. Badu's decisive goal showcased the home team's strategic quick moves and capitalized on Milan's defensive lapses. Fans might have hoped for better fluidity and fewer stoppages, but Udinese's tactical discipline and quick counters proved too much for Milan on the day.
